content.title: Central Banking
content.definition: A central bank is a public institution that manages a country's currency, money supply, and interest rates. It serves as the banker to the government and commercial banks, conducts monetary policy to achieve macroeconomic objectives (typically price stability and maximum employment), acts as lender of last resort during financial crises, and often supervises the banking system. Major central banks include the Federal Reserve (US), European Central Bank (ECB), Bank of Japan (BOJ), Bank of England (BOE), and People's Bank of China (PBOC). Central bank independence from political control is considered essential for credible anti-inflationary policy.

definitions_glossary.central_bank: A nation's monetary authority - controls money supply, sets interest rates, oversees banking system, issues currency
definitions_glossary.federal_reserve: The US central bank, established 1913, with dual mandate: maximum employment and price stability
definitions_glossary.monetary_policy: Central bank actions to influence money supply and interest rates - main tools: OMO, discount rate, reserve requirements
definitions_glossary.open_market_operations: Fed buying/selling government securities to inject/drain reserves and influence federal funds rate
definitions_glossary.federal_funds_rate: The interest rate banks charge each other for overnight lending of reserves - Fed's primary policy target
definitions_glossary.discount_rate: Interest rate charged by Fed on loans to commercial banks through discount window - penalty rate above fed funds
definitions_glossary.reserve_requirements: Minimum reserves banks must hold against deposits - tool for controlling money multiplier (now 0% in US)
definitions_glossary.lender_of_last_resort: Central bank role to provide liquidity to solvent but illiquid banks during crises - prevents bank runs
definitions_glossary.price_stability: Low and stable inflation - typically 2% target for major central banks
definitions_glossary.dual_mandate: Fed's two equal objectives: maximum employment and price stability (unique compared to ECB's single mandate)
definitions_glossary.central_bank_independence: Separation of monetary policy from political control - reduces inflation bias from electoral pressures
definitions_glossary.inflation_targeting: Monetary policy framework with explicit inflation target - enhances transparency and anchors expectations
definitions_glossary.quantitative_easing: Large-scale asset purchases when interest rates at zero - unconventional monetary policy expanding balance sheet

key_points: Central banks control monetary policy: Setting interest rates and managing money supply to achieve macro objectives
Fed dual mandate: Maximum employment and price stability (2% inflation target) - balancing competing goals
Primary tool: Open market operations - buying/selling bonds to influence federal funds rate and bank reserves
Lender of last resort: Provide emergency liquidity to prevent bank runs and systemic crises (Bagehot's rule: lend freely at penalty rate)
Central bank independence crucial: Insulates policy from short-term political pressures, enhances credibility, lowers inflation
Inflation targeting: Explicit numerical target (2%) anchors expectations, increases transparency and accountability
Zero lower bound problem: When rates hit 0%, conventional policy exhausted - resort to QE, forward guidance
Financial stability role expanded after 2008: Macroprudential supervision, stress testing, systemic risk monitoring
Fed structure: 12 regional banks, 7-member Board of Governors, FOMC (12 voting members) sets policy
Taylor Rule: r = r* + 0.5(π - π*) + 0.5(Y - Y*) - guideline for setting interest rates based on inflation and output gaps

examples.title: Fed Response to 2008 Financial Crisis
examples.description: Lehman Brothers collapsed September 2008, triggering global financial panic. Fed cut federal funds rate from 5.25% to 0-0.25% by December 2008. When conventional policy exhausted, launched QE1 ($1.75T asset purchases), followed by QE2 and QE3. Provided emergency lending to AIG, Bear Stearns, and through various liquidity facilities (TAF, CPFF, TALF). Total Fed balance sheet expanded from $900B to $4.5T. Demonstrated all central bank functions: lender of last resort, aggressive monetary easing, financial stability intervention.
examples.context: Comprehensive crisis response using conventional and unconventional tools
examples.data: Fed funds: 5.25% → 0.25% (2007-2008). Balance sheet: $900B → $4.5T (2008-2014). Emergency lending: $2T+ at peak

examples.title: Volcker Disinflation (1979-1982)
examples.description: Paul Volcker became Fed Chair in 1979 with inflation at 13%. Dramatically raised federal funds rate to 20% (June 1981), highest in history. Caused severe recession (unemployment 10.8%) but broke inflationary expectations. By 1983, inflation fell to 3%. Demonstrated: (1) Central bank can conquer inflation if willing to accept short-term costs, (2) Credibility of commitment essential - Volcker maintained tight policy despite political pressure, (3) Independent central bank can make unpopular but necessary decisions.
examples.context: Establishing central bank credibility through painful disinflation

examples.title: ECB and Eurozone Debt Crisis (2010-2015)
examples.description: Greek debt crisis threatened euro breakup. ECB initially constrained by single mandate (price stability only) and prohibition on financing governments. Turning point: Draghi's 'whatever it takes' speech (July 2012) and OMT program announcement. Bond spreads collapsed immediately even though OMT never used. Later launched QE (2015) despite German opposition. Illustrates: (1) Central bank credibility/communication as powerful tool, (2) Single mandate limitations, (3) Political constraints on central bank action.
examples.context: Central bank navigating political constraints in currency union
examples.data: Spanish 10-year spread: 650bp (July 2012) → 250bp (Sept 2012). ECB QE: €2.6T asset purchases (2015-2018)

examples.title: Bank of Japan Negative Interest Rates (2016)
examples.description: Fighting decades of deflation, BOJ cut policy rate to -0.1% in January 2016 (after ECB went negative in 2014). Banks charged for excess reserves at BOJ, intended to push lending. Mixed results: yen initially depreciated (boosting exports), but banks' profitability squeezed, cash hoarding increased. Illustrates: (1) Limits of monetary policy near zero, (2) Unintended consequences of unconventional policy, (3) Difficulty escaping deflationary trap even with aggressive central bank action.
examples.data: BOJ policy rate: 0% → -0.1% (Jan 2016). Yen: ¥118/$ → ¥100/$ initially, then reversal. CPI inflation: still near 0%

examples.title: Fed's 2022-2023 Inflation Fight
examples.description: Post-COVID inflation surged to 9.1% (June 2022). Fed pivoted from 'transitory' view, began aggressive tightening: raised fed funds rate from 0.25% to 5.25-5.50% (fastest pace since 1980s). Also began quantitative tightening (shrinking balance sheet). Unemployment remained low (3.5-4%), 'soft landing' optimism. Debate: Did Fed wait too long? Is 2% target still appropriate? Demonstrated: (1) Inflation-fighting remains core function, (2) Credibility concerns when behind the curve, (3) Taylor Rule suggested earlier tightening needed.
examples.context: Modern inflation-fighting episode after long period of low inflation

content.statement: Central banking is the institutional foundation of modern monetary systems. Central banks control money supply and interest rates to pursue macroeconomic objectives (price stability, maximum employment), serve as lender of last resort during financial crises, and increasingly oversee financial stability. Understanding central bank functions, tools, independence, and limitations is essential for analyzing monetary policy and macroeconomic outcomes.

explanation.intuition: Think of the central bank as the economy's thermostat and emergency fire department combined. As thermostat: it adjusts interest rates to keep the economy at the right 'temperature' - not too hot (inflation) or too cold (recession). Raise rates to cool overheating, cut rates to warm up a cold economy. As fire department: when financial panic threatens (bank runs, market seizures), the central bank provides emergency liquidity - lending freely to stop the fire from spreading. The central bank's independence is like giving the thermostat to an expert rather than letting people who want it warmer or cooler today control it - the expert focuses on long-term stable temperature, not short-term comfort.
explanation.key_insight: The most important insight is that central bank effectiveness depends critically on credibility and expectations. If people believe the central bank will maintain 2% inflation, they set wages and prices accordingly, and 2% becomes self-fulfilling. If they doubt the commitment, expectations become unanchored and inflation spirals. This is why independence matters: politicians facing elections have incentive to stimulate before voting (inflation later), creating 'inflation bias.' An independent central bank focused on long-term price stability doesn't face this temptation. Credibility also explains 'whatever it takes' power: Draghi's words alone moved markets because investors believed the ECB would act. Credibility is the central bank's most valuable asset - once lost, very costly to rebuild (as Volcker demonstrated).
explanation.technical_details: Fed's operational framework: Target federal funds rate (overnight interbank lending). Open market operations: Buy Treasury bonds → pay with reserves → more reserves → lower fed funds rate. Sell bonds → drain reserves → higher rate. Post-2008 with ample reserves: Interest on reserves (IOR) creates floor for fed funds (why lend below what Fed pays?). Overnight reverse repo (ON RRP) creates subfloor for non-bank lenders. Fed controls rate through corridor/floor system, not reserve scarcity. Taylor Rule: r = r* + 0.5(π - π*) + 0.5(y - y*) where r* = equilibrium real rate (≈2%), π* = target inflation (2%), y = output gap. Example: If inflation = 4%, output gap = 2%: r = 2 + 0.5(4-2) + 0.5(2) = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4% nominal. Central bank balance sheet: Assets (Treasuries, MBS, loans) = Liabilities (currency, reserves, reverse repo) + Capital.

mathematical_formulation.modified_taylor_rule: r = r* + 1.5(π - π*) + 0.5(Y - Y*)/Y* - Taylor principle: coefficient > 1 on inflation
mathematical_formulation.fisher_equation: i = r + πᵉ - nominal rate = real rate + expected inflation
mathematical_formulation.money_demand_equilibrium: M/P = L(Y, i) determines equilibrium interest rate
mathematical_formulation.reaction_function: i_t = i_{t-1} + α(π_t - π*) + β(y_t - y*) - interest rate smoothing
mathematical_formulation.seigniorage: S = ΔM/P - revenue from money creation accruing to government

conventional_tools.open_market_operations: Buying/selling securities to adjust reserves and influence short-term rates
conventional_tools.discount_rate: Penalty rate for emergency borrowing - typically 50-100bp above target rate
conventional_tools.reserve_requirements: Minimum reserves as fraction of deposits - rarely changed (now 0% in US)

unconventional_tools.quantitative_easing: Large-scale asset purchases to lower long-term rates when short rates at zero
unconventional_tools.forward_guidance: Communication about future policy path to shape expectations
unconventional_tools.negative_interest_rates: Charging banks for reserves to encourage lending (ECB, BOJ, SNB)
unconventional_tools.credit_easing: Purchasing private assets (corporate bonds, MBS) to support specific markets

emergency_tools.discount_window: Short-term lending to banks against collateral
emergency_tools.emergency_lending_13_3: Fed authority to lend to non-banks in 'unusual and exigent circumstances'
emergency_tools.swap_lines: Currency swaps with foreign central banks to provide dollar liquidity globally

central_bank_independence.goal_independence: Central bank chooses own objectives - rare, ECB has this for price stability
central_bank_independence.instrument_independence: Central bank chooses how to achieve politically-set goals - Fed has this
central_bank_independence.rationale: Time-inconsistency problem (Kydland-Prescott): Politicians tempted to inflate for short-term employment gains
central_bank_independence.evidence: Cross-country studies show independent central banks achieve lower average inflation (Alesina & Summers, 1993)
central_bank_independence.accountability: Independence balanced by transparency, congressional testimony, inflation targets

concepts: Taylor Rule: Linear relationship between rates and gaps
Optimization: Central bank loss function minimization
Central bank independence: Delegation and accountability
Political business cycles: Electoral pressures on policy
Institutional design: Rules vs discretion debate
Interest rate risk: Managing exposure to Fed policy
Corporate finance: Cost of capital affected by rates
Fed creation 1913: Response to banking panics
Great Inflation 1970s: Lessons for central banking

verified_claims.claim: Taylor Rule: r = r* + 0.5(π - π*) + 0.5(y - y*)
verified_claims.derivation: Original Taylor (1993) formulation: r = 2 + π + 0.5(π - 2) + 0.5(y - y*). Simplified: r = r* + 1.5(π - π*) + 0.5(y - y*) with r* = 2%, π* = 2% ✓

verified_claims.claim: Taylor Principle: Coefficient on inflation gap should exceed 1 for stability
verified_claims.derivation: If real rate doesn't rise with inflation (coefficient < 1), inflation becomes self-reinforcing. Coefficient > 1 ensures real rate rises, cooling economy ✓

verified_claims.claim: Central bank independence correlated with lower inflation
verified_claims.derivation: Alesina & Summers (1993) cross-country regression: Higher independence index → lower average inflation and inflation variance. Robust finding replicated in subsequent studies ✓
Investor indifferent between: (1) Nominal bond paying i, (2) Real return r plus inflation compensation. No arbitrage requires: 1+i = (1+r)(1+πᵉ) ≈ 1+r+πᵉ, so i = r + πᵉ ✓
